asking: You have an EC2 instance running a web application. You’ve lately seen large increases in traffic and the application is responding slowly several times a day. What are the best steps to take to ensure consistent performance? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Create a launch configuration with an AMI ID and instance parameters.
Create an Auto Scaling group from the current EC2 instance.
Set up an Auto Scaling group with demand-based scaling.
Set up an Auto Scaling group with manual scaling.

rightAnswer.description: All of these are acceptable options, but the best options are to use the existing EC2 instance as a basis for a new Auto Scaling group and to set up demand-based scaling. Anytime you have an existing instance that is working, you can simply start from there, rather than using a launch configuration and duplicating the setup. Demand-based scaling will respond to changing conditions better than having to manually scale up and down or to set a desired capacity (which is unknown based on the question).

asking: You have an application that is peaking daily. You have determined that a large user base on the East Coast is accessing the application every evening, causing the application’s per-formance to degrade during those hours. What steps would you take to level out perfor-mance? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Create an Auto Scaling group with schedule-based scaling.
Consider hosting your Auto Scaling group in a US East region.
Implement CloudFront to cache responses to user requests.
Set up an Auto Scaling group with manual scaling.

rightAnswer.description: This is a case of having a recurring performance issue, which points to using schedule-based scaling. Further, you know that access is centered around the US East regions. C might help the issue, but without knowing more about the application, it’s not possible to tell if caching content would significantly improve performance.

asking: You are in charge of the backup processes for converting an in-house network storage sys-tem to S3 on AWS. You want to minimize the costs of cloud storage but preserve the low-est possible latency for requests to the cloud-hosted files. What storage class would you suggest?

rightAnswer.description: Here, the determining factor is the requirement of instant access. S3 One Zone-IA will give you that access, at a lower cost than S3 standard and S3-IA. According to AWS, all three classes have the same first byte latency (milliseconds).

asking: Which of the following will take the longest to retrieve data from?

rightAnswer.description: Glacier takes 3–5 hours to deliver the first byte.

asking: Which of the following will take the longest to retrieve data from?

rightAnswer.description: This is easy to miss, and often is. All three of these S3 storage classes share the same first-byte latency: milliseconds.

asking: You are in charge of a CPU-intensive application that has been refactored to perform the most compute-heavy portions of processing separate from normal daily operations. These compute-heavy tasks must finish every month but can be stopped and started without affecting the overall progress of the job. You want to reduce costs associated with this processing; which instance pricing model would you suggest?

rightAnswer.description: Spot instances offer you significant costs savings as long as you have flexibility and application processes can be stopped and started.

asking: When creating a new security group, which of the following are true? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: All inbound traffic is allowed by default.
All outbound traffic is allowed by default.
Connections that are allowed in must also explicitly be allowed back out.
Connections that are allowed in are automatically allowed back out.

rightAnswer.description: Option A is false, but option B is true. Default security groups prevent all traffic in and allow all traffic out. Options C and D are about whether or not a security group is stateful: whether an incoming connection automatically can get back out. Security groups are stateful, so D is true. If the subject of the question was a NACL, then option C would be true, as NACLs are stateless.

asking: You have a government-regulated system that will store a large amount of data on S3 standard. You must encrypt all data and preserve a clear audit trail for traceability and third-party auditing. Security policies dictate that encryption must be consistent across the entire data store. Which of the following encryption approaches would be best?

answerOption.description: Encrypt the data prior to upload to S3 and decrypt the data when returning it to the client.

rightAnswer.description: D is not a good answer because relying on encryption outside of S3 does not best address the concerns around consistency. It is generally better to allow AWS to handle encryption in cases where you want to ensure all encryption is the same across a data store. SSE-C, SSE-KMS, and SSE-C all provide this. However, among those three, KMS is the best option for providing clear audit trails.

asking: You are creating a bastion host to allow SSH access to a set of EC2 instances in a private subnet within your organization’s VPC. Which of the following should be done as part of configuring the bastion host? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Ensure that the bastion host is exposed directly to the Internet.
Place the bastion host within the private subnet.
Add a route from the bastion host IP into the private subnet into the subnet’s NACLs.
Ensure that the bastion host is within the same security group as the hosts within the private subnet.

rightAnswer.description: A bastion host is a publicly accessible host that allows traffic to connect to it. Then, an additional connection is made from the bastion host into a private subnet and the hosts within that subnet. Because the bastion must be accessed by public clients, it must be exposed to the Internet (A). If it is within a private subnet (B), it will not be accessible, making that answer incorrect. There also must be an explicit route from the bastion host into the private subnet (C); this is usually within a NACL. Finally, the security of the bastion must be different from the hosts in the private subnet. The bastion host should be hardened significantly as it is public, but also accessible; this is in many ways the opposite of the security requirements of hosts within a private subnet.

asking: Which of the following are invalid IAM actions? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Limiting the root account SSH access to all EC2 instances
Allowing a user account SSH access to all EC2 instances
Removing console access for the root account
Removing console access for all non-root user accounts

rightAnswer.description: AWS sometimes asks questions like this to ensure that you understand that the root account is truly a root account and you cannot restrict that account’s access. Anything that involves removing access for the root account is always invalid.

asking: Which of the following statements is true?

answerOption.description: You should store application keys only in your application’s .aws file.
You should never store your application keys on an instance, in an AMI, or anywhere else permanent on the cloud.
You should only store application keys in an encrypted AMI.
You should only use your application key to log in to the AWS console.

rightAnswer.description: This is a “gimme question” that AWS will often ask on exams. You should never store your application keys on an instance, in an AMI, or anywhere else permanent on the cloud—meaning option B is true. Additionally, D makes no sense; application keys are for programmatic access, not console access.

asking: Your company is setting up a VPN connection to connect its local network to an AWS VPC. Which of the following components are not necessary for this setup? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: A private subnet in the AWS VPC

rightAnswer.description: Site-to-site VPN connections require a virtual private gateway (on the AWS side) and a customer gateway (on the local side). A private subnet is optional, but not required, as is a NAT instance.

asking: You have a private subnet in a VPC within AWS. The instances within the subnet are unable to access the Internet. You have created a NAT gateway to solve this problem. What additional steps do you need to perform to allow the instances Internet access? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Ensure that the NAT gateway is in the same subnet as the instances that cannot access the Internet.
Add a route in the private subnet to route traffic aimed at 0.0.0.0/0 at the NAT  gateway.
Add a route in the public subnet to route traffic aimed at 0.0.0.0/0 at the NAT  gateway.
Ensure that the NAT gateway is in a public subnet.

rightAnswer.description: There are two pairs of answers here, and you need to choose the correct pair in each case. For private subnet instances, you need a route out to a NAT gateway, and that NAT gateway must be in a public subnet—otherwise, it would not itself be able to provide outbound traffic access to the Internet. That means option D is correct, as is answer B: 0.0.0.0/0 means “traffic with a destination in the Internet at large,” more or less.

asking: Which of the following statements regarding NAT instances and NAT gateways are false? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Both NAT instances and NAT gateways are highly available.
You must choose the instance type and size when creating a NAT gateway but not when creating a NAT instance.
It is your responsibility to patch a NAT instance and AWS’s responsibility to patch a NAT gateway.
You assign a security group to a NAT instance but not to a NAT gateway.

rightAnswer.description: The easiest way to handle this question is by thinking of a NAT gateway as essentially a managed service and a NAT instance as an instance (which you manage) for networking. That helps identify B as false (you never choose instance types and sizes for managed services) and C as true (AWS patches managed services). Further, since AWS manages NAT gateways, they are automatically highly available and do not need you to associate security groups. This means that A is false—NAT instances can be made highly available, but not without your manual intervention—and D is true.

asking: Which of the following statements is true?

answerOption.description: A VPC’s default NACLs allow all inbound and outbound traffic.
Traffic allowed into a NACL is automatically allowed back out.

rightAnswer.description: Option A is true, and if you know that, this is an easy question. However, it doesn’t seem obvious, as all custom NACLs disallow all inbound and outbound traffic. It is only a VPC’s default NACL that has an “allow all” policy. As for B and C, these are both reversed: NACLs are stateless (allowing independent configuration of inbound and outbound traffic) and security groups are stateful. This also explains why D is false: NACLs are stateless.

asking: You have changed the permissions associated with a role, and that role is assigned to an existing running EC2 instance. When will the permissions you updated take effect for the instance?

answerOption.description: The next time the EC2 instance is restarted

rightAnswer.description: Permission changes to a role now take place immediately and apply to all instances using that role.

asking: Which of the following statements is true?

answerOption.description: When creating a new security group, by default, all traffic is allowed in, including SSH.
If you need inbound HTTP and HTTPS access, create a new security group and accept the default settings.
You must explicitly allow any inbound traffic into a new security group.

rightAnswer.description: If an allow-everything doesn’t set off alarm bells, the reference to SSH should. Security groups, by default, don’t allow any traffic in. They require you to explicitly allow inbound traffic (C); the other options are all false. And security groups are stateful—remember this, as it will come up in almost every single exam.

asking: Which of the following statements is not true?

answerOption.description: When creating a new security group, by default, no inbound traffic is allowed.
When creating a new security group, by default, all traffic is allowed out, including SSH.
When creating a new security group, by default, all traffic is allowed out, with the exception of SSH.
When creating a new security group, inbound HTTPS traffic is not allowed.

rightAnswer.description: All outbound traffic is allowed to pass out of a VPC by default, although no inbound traffic is allowed.

asking: How would you enable encryption of your EBS volumes?

answerOption.description: Use the AWS CLI with the aws security command.
Take a snapshot of the EBS volume and copy it to an encrypted S3 bucket.
Select the encryption option when creating the EBS volume.
Encrypt the volume using the encryption tools of the operating system of the EC2 instance that has mounted the EBS volume.

rightAnswer.description: EBS volumes can be encrypted when they are created. All other options typically affect snapshots of the volume, but not the volume itself.

asking: What types of rules does a security group allow? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Security groups only contain allow rules, not deny rules (and prevent rules are not an actual rule type). Then, you can create both inbound and outbound rules.

asking: Which of the following are true about security groups? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: You can specify deny rules, but not allow rules.
By default, a security group includes an outbound rule that allows all outbound  traffic.
You can specify specific separate rules for inbound and outbound traffic.

rightAnswer.description: You specify allow rules for security groups, so A is false. B and C are true: Default security groups allow all outbound traffic, and you specify separate inbound and outbound rules. Finally, security groups are stateful, not stateless, so D is false.

asking: Which of the following are not true about security groups? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Allow rules take priority over deny rules.
Responses to allowed inbound traffic are allowed to flow back out.
You can specify specific separate rules for inbound and outbound traffic.
If there are no outbound rules, then all outbound traffic is allowed to flow out.

rightAnswer.description: A is false, as security groups don’t provide for deny rules. B and C are both true (and therefore are not correct answers). D is false, because without specific outbound rules, nothing is allowed to flow out. (Note that by default, there is an allowance for all outgoing traffic in security groups, although that can be removed.)

asking: Which of the following must a security group have when you create it? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: A security group can actually have no inbound or outbound rules, so A and D are not required. A security group does require a name and description, though.

asking: Which of the following is a security group associated with?

rightAnswer.description: A security group can be attached to multiple constructs, like an EC2 instance, but is ultimately associated with a network interface, which in turn is attached to individual instances. This is a tough question and probably at the very edge of what the exam might ask.

asking: Which of the following are default rules on a default security group, such as the one that comes with the default VPC? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: The easiest way to work this is to recognize that default security groups never allow broad inbound traffic. That eliminates B and D and leaves rules that allow all outbound traffic for both IPv4 (A) and IPv6 (C).

asking: Which of the following are parts of a security group rule? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Security group rules have a protocol and a description. They do not have a subnet, although they can have CIDR blocks or single IP addresses. Instances can associate with a security group, but a security group does not itself refer to a specific instance.

asking: Which of the following allows you to securely upload data to S3? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: They key here is not the endpoint, but the actual protocol used to access the endpoint. In this case, HTTPS is secure, while HTTP is not, so the answers using HTTPS—B and C—are correct.

asking: Which of the following describes client-side encryption for S3 bucket data?

answerOption.description: You encrypt and upload data to S3, managing the encryption process yourself.
You encrypt and upload data to S3, allowing AWS to manage the encryption process.
You request AWS to encrypt an object before saving it to S3.
You encrypt an object, but AWS uploads and decrypts the object.

rightAnswer.description: Client-side encryption involves the client (you, in this example) managing the entire encryption and decryption process. AWS only provides storage.

asking: Which of the following describes server-side encryption for S3 bucket data?

answerOption.description: You encrypt and upload data to S3, managing the encryption process yourself.
You encrypt and upload data to S3, allowing AWS to manage the encryption process.
You request AWS to encrypt an object before saving it to S3.
You encrypt an object, but AWS uploads and decrypts the object.

rightAnswer.description: With server-side encryption, AWS handles all the object encryption and decryption.

asking: Which of the following are valid steps in enabling client-side encryption for S3? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Download the AWS CLI and SSH to your S3 key store.
Use a KMS-managed customer master key.
Download an AWS SDK for encrypting data on the client side.
Turn on bucket encryption for the target S3 buckets.

rightAnswer.description: For client-side encryption, you’ll need a master key, which can either be a KMS-managed key (option B) or a client-side master key. You’ll also need an SDK for encrypting the client-side data (C).

asking: Which of the following is not a way to manage server-side encryption keys for S3?

rightAnswer.description: You’ll probably simply need to memorize this one. SSE-S3, SSE-KMS, and SSE-C are all valid approaches to S3 encryption; SSE-E is made up.

asking: Which of the following encryption key management options is best for ensuring strong audit trails?

rightAnswer.description: The word audit should be a trigger for you: always choose KMS when you see a need for strong auditing. SSE-KMS provides a very good audit trail and security, perhaps the best of all these options for most use cases.

asking: Which of the following encryption key management options is best for managing keys but allowing S3 to handle the actual encryption of data?

rightAnswer.description: SSE-C allows the customer (the C in SSE-C) to manage keys, but S3 then handles the actual encryption of data.

asking: You have a customer that has a legacy security group that is very suspicious of all things security in the cloud. The customer wants to use S3, but doesn’t trust AWS encryption, and you need to enable its migration to the cloud. What option would you recommend to address the company’s concerns?

rightAnswer.description: Client-side encryption allows the customer to manage keys and encrypt data themselves, then store the data on S3 already encrypted. There’s a lot of overhead with this approach, but it’s ideal for the use case described.

asking: You want to begin encrypting your S3 data, but your organization is new to encryption. Which option is a low-cost approach that still offloads most of the work to AWS rather than the organization new to encryption?

rightAnswer.description: In general, SSE-S3 is the “starter” option for encryption. It’s by no means a simple or amateur approach to security, but it is low cost compared to KMS and has much less overhead than client-side or SSE-C encryption keys.

asking: You are the architect for a company whose data must comply with current EU privacy restrictions. Which of the following S3 buckets are valid options? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Here, you must recognize that EU West and EU Central are both EU regions and the other two options are not.

asking: Which of the following options could be used to provide availability-zone-resilient fault-tolerant storage that complies with EU privacy laws? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: S3 One Zone-IA buckets in EU-West-1

rightAnswer.description: Option A isn’t valid because US-West isn’t an EU region. Options B and C are valid as they both provide EU regions, and S3 and S3-IA both can survive the loss of an availability zone; option D would not survive the loss of an AZ.

asking: What type of replication will your Multi-AZ RDS instances use?

rightAnswer.description: Multi-AZ RDS instances use synchronous replication to push changes.

asking: You want to provide maximum protection against data in your S3 object storage being deleted accidentally. What should you do?

answerOption.description: Enable versioning on your EBS volumes.
Turn on MFA Delete on your S3 buckets.
Set up a Lambda job to monitor and block delete requests to S3.
Turn off the DELETE endpoints on the S3 REST API.

rightAnswer.description: MFA Delete is the most powerful anti-deletion protection you can provide without disabling delete via IAM roles. Option A doesn’t affect your object storage—EBS is block storage. Options C and D both won’t help; delete requests can’t be blocked by Lambda, and there is no “DELETE endpoint” on the S3 API.

asking: You want to provide maximum protection against data in your S3 object storage being deleted accidentally. What steps should you take? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Enable versioning on your S3 buckets.
Turn on MFA Delete on your S3 buckets.
Enable versioning in CloudWatch’s S3 API.
Remove IAM permissions for deleting objects for all users.

rightAnswer.description: MFA Delete is the right option here (B), but A is a required step to enable MFA Delete. Option C doesn’t actually make sense, and while option D would technically prevent all deletions, it isn’t what the question is asking: You must prevent accidental deletions, not remove the ability to delete objects altogether.

asking: You want to enable MFA Delete on your S3 buckets in the US East 1 region. What step must you take before enabling MFA Delete?

answerOption.description: Disable the REST API for the buckets on which you want MFA Delete.
Enable cross-region replication on the buckets on which you want MFA Delete.
Move the buckets to a region that supports MFA Delete, such as US West 1.
Enable versioning on the buckets on which you want MFA Delete.

rightAnswer.description: You must enable versioning to enable MFA Delete. The region of the bucket doesn’t have any effect here (B and C), and there is no way to disable the REST API (A), although you could remove programmatic access via IAM or removal of access keys.

asking: What is AWS Trusted Advisor?

answerOption.description: An online resource to help you improve performance
An online resource to help you reduce cost
An online resource to help you improve security

rightAnswer.description: AWS Trusted Advisor does all three of the above: improve performance, reduce cost, and improve security.

asking: On which of the following does AWS Trusted Advisor not provide recommendations?

rightAnswer.description: AWS Trusted Advisor provides advice on cost, fault tolerance, performance, and security but does not address account organization.

asking: Which of the following are included in the core AWS Trusted Advisor checks?  (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Here, it’s not reasonable to memorize the seven core AWS Trusted Advisor checks. Instead, consider which of these are valid improvements that Trusted Advisor might make. A and B relate to security and permissions, while both C and D are pretty far afield of cost, security, or performance suggestions.

asking: Which of the following recommendations might AWS Trusted Advisor make?  (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Turn on MFA for the root account.
Turn on antivirus protection for EC2 instances.
Update S3 buckets with public write access.
Update NAT instances to NAT gateways.

rightAnswer.description: This is tricky. First, MFA on the root account is a standard recommendation, so you can select that. For the remaining three answers, the one that is most directly a “common security recommendation” would have to be S3 buckets with write access, and that is the correct answer.

asking: Which of the following is not possible using IAM policies?

answerOption.description: Requiring MFA for the root account
Denying the root account access to EC2 instances
Disabling S3 access for users in a group
Restricting SSH access to EC2 instances to a specific user

rightAnswer.description: The only one of these that’s not possible with IAM is denying the root account access to EC2 instances. That’s not possible—with IAM or any other mechanism.

asking: Which of the following are not true about S3 encryption? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: S3 applies AWS-256 encryption to data when server-side encryption is enabled.
S3 encryption will use a client key if it is supplied with data.
Encrypted EBS volumes can only be stored if server-side encryption is enabled.
S3 will accept locally encrypted data if client-side encryption is enabled.

rightAnswer.description: A is true, and D is true; if you know this, choosing B and C is simple. Otherwise, you need to recognize that just supplying a client key to S3 is not enough; some form of client-side encryption or server-side encryption using client keys must be enabled. EBS volumes can be encrypted outside of S3 and stored regardless of how S3 is encrypting data.

asking: What types of data are encrypted when you create an encrypted EBS volume?  (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Data at rest inside the volume
Data moving between the volume and the attached instance
Data inside S3 buckets that store the encrypted instance
Data in an EFS on instances attached to the volume

rightAnswer.description: There are four types of data encrypted when an EBS volume is encrypted: data at rest on the volume, data moving between the volume and the instance, any snapshots created from the volume, and any volumes created from those snapshots.

asking: What types of data are not automatically encrypted when you create an encrypted EBS volume? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: A snapshot created from the EBS volume
Any data on additional volumes attached to the same instance as the encrypted  volume
Data created on an instance that has the encrypted volume attached
Data moving between the volume and the attached instance

rightAnswer.description: This is tricky, as both answers that involve unencrypted data have some tricky wording. First, B is not a case of encryption; if data never touches the encrypted volume, it is not automatically encrypted. Second, for C, data that is on the instance but never moves to the encrypted volume is also not automatically encrypted.

asking: What of the following types of data is not encrypted automatically when an encrypted EBS volume is attached to an EC2 instance?

answerOption.description: Data in transit to the volume
Data at rest on the volume
Data in transit from the volume

rightAnswer.description: All of these are encrypted. Data moving to and from the volume as well as data at rest on the volume are all encrypted.

asking: What encryption service is used by encrypted EBS volumes?

rightAnswer.description: KMS is used as the encryption service, but this is not the S3-KMS that is specific to S3 encryption. You will also sometimes see this KMS referenced as AWS-KMS.

asking: How can you access the private IP address of a running EC2 instance?

rightAnswer.description: This is a case of pure memorization. The URL is always http://169.254.169.254 and the metadata, which is what you want, is at /latest/meta-data/.

asking: If you take a snapshot of an encrypted EBS volume, which of the following will be true? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: All data on the bucket on which the snapshot is stored will be encrypted.
Any instances using the snapshot will be encrypted.
Any volumes created from the snapshot will be encrypted.

rightAnswer.description: Encryption of a volume affects snapshots of the volume and instances created from that snapshot, but nothing else.

asking: If you take a snapshot of an encrypted EBS volume, which of the following must you do to use that snapshot as a volume in a separate region? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Copy the snapshot to the new region.
Delete the snapshot from the old region.
Unencrypt the snapshot once it is in the new region.
Create a new volume from the snapshot in the new region.

rightAnswer.description: The only steps required here are to copy the snapshot to the new region (usually via the console), and then create a new volume from it.

asking: How do you encrypt an RDS instance?

answerOption.description: Enable encryption on the running instance via the CLI.
Enable encryption on the running instance via the console.
Run the encryption process on the running instance via the console.
Enable encryption when creating the instance.

rightAnswer.description: You cannot encrypt a running instance; you have to create the instance with encryption enabled.

asking: Which of the following will ensure that data on your RDS instance is encrypted?

answerOption.description: Enable encryption on the running RDS instance via the AWS API.
Encrypt the instance on which RDS is running.
None of these will encrypt all data on the instance.

rightAnswer.description: You cannot encrypt a running RDS instance, so B is incorrect, and you have no access to the underlying instance for RDS, so C is also incorrect. Option A sounds possible, but it will not address any data created by the database itself (such as indices, references to other data in the database, etc.). The only way to encrypt an RDS instance is to encrypt it at creation of the instance.

asking: Which of the following will allow you to bring a non-encrypted RDS instance into com-pliance with an “all data must be encrypted at rest” policy?

answerOption.description: Snapshot the RDS instance and restore it, encrypting the new copy upon restoration.
Use the AWS Database Migration Service to migrate the data from the instance to an encrypted instance.
Create a new encrypted instance and manually move data into it.
None of these will encrypt all data on the instance.

rightAnswer.description: The only option here is the manual one. You must set up encryption when creating a new instance from scratch (snapshots won’t work) and then move data into it so that this data is encrypted as it moves into the new instance.

asking: Which of the following will allow you to bring a non-encrypted EBS volume into compli-ance with an “all data must be encrypted at rest” policy?

answerOption.description: Stop the volume, snapshot it, and encrypt a copy of the snapshot. Then restore from the encrypted snapshot.
Stop the volume, select “Turn on encryption,” and restart the volume.
Encrypt the volume via the AWS API and turn on the “encrypt existing data” flag.
None of these will encrypt all data on the volume.

rightAnswer.description: You cannot encrypt an existing volume “on the fly.” You must create a snapshot and then encrypt that snapshot as you copy it to another, encrypted snapshot. You can then restore from that new snapshot.

asking: Which of the following will allow you to bring a non-encrypted EBS volume into compli-ance with an “all data must be encrypted at rest” policy?

answerOption.description: Stop the volume, create a snapshot, and restart from the snapshot, selecting “Encrypt this volume.”
Stop the volume, select “Turn on encryption,” and restart the volume.
Encrypt the volume via the AWS API and turn on the “encrypt existing data” flag.
None of these will encrypt all data on the volume.

rightAnswer.description: None of these will work. The important thing to remember for a question like this is that you must make a copy of an unencrypted snapshot to apply encryption. There is no in-place encryption mechanism for volumes or snapshots.

asking: Which of the following will allow you to bring a non-encrypted EBS volume into compli-ance with an “all data must be encrypted at rest” policy?

answerOption.description: Create a new volume, attach the new volume to an EC2 instance, copy the data from the non-encrypted volume to the new volume, and then encrypt the new volume.
Create a new volume with encryption turned on, attach the new volume to an EC2 instance, and copy the data from the non-encrypted volume to the new volume.
Create a new volume, attach the new volume to an EC2 instance, and use the encrypted-copy command to copy the data from the non-encrypted volume to the new volume.
None of these will encrypt all data on the volume.

rightAnswer.description: The only way to encrypt an EBS volume is to encrypt it at creation time. Remembering this one detail will help on lots of questions in this vein.

asking: Which of the following are valid options on an EBS volume? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Encrypt a snapshot of the volume.
Encrypt a copy of a snapshot of the volume.
Restore an encrypted snapshot to an encrypted volume.

rightAnswer.description: You cannot encrypt an existing EBS volume, so A is incorrect. And you cannot encrypt a snapshot that is unencrypted, so B is incorrect. You can encrypt a copy of a snapshot and restore an encrypted snapshot to a volume that is encrypted (C and D).

asking: Which of the following are not true about EBS snapshots? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Snapshots of encrypted volumes are automatically encrypted.
When you copy an encrypted snapshot, the copy is not encrypted unless you explicitly specify.
You cannot copy an encrypted snapshot unless you unencrypt the snapshot first.
Volumes that are created from encrypted snapshots are automatically encrypted.

rightAnswer.description: Snapshots of encrypted volumes stay encrypted—whether you copy them (B and C) or create volumes from them (D). So A and D are true, while B and C are false.

asking: Can you copy a snapshot across AWS accounts?

answerOption.description: Yes, but you first have to modify the snapshot’s access permissions.
Yes, but you have to be the owner of both AWS accounts.

rightAnswer.description: You can copy snapshots across accounts, but the default permissions do not allow this. So you have to modify those permissions, and then the snapshot can be copied to any other AWS account, regardless of account owner.

asking: You have a snapshot of an EBS volume in US East 2. You want to create a volume from this snapshot in US West 1. Is this possible?

answerOption.description: Yes, create the volume in US West 1 based upon the snapshot in US East 2.
Yes, but you’ll need to copy the snapshot to US West 1 first.
Yes, but you’ll need to create the instance in US East 2 and then move it to US West 1.

rightAnswer.description: You can only create volumes from snapshots in the same region. Since the instance is desired in US West 1, a copy of the snapshot must be made in that region first, so B is correct.

asking: Can you copy an EBS snapshot across regions?

answerOption.description: Yes, as long as the snapshot is not encrypted.
Yes, as long as the snapshot is marked for multi-region use.

rightAnswer.description: You can copy a snapshot to a different region without any special considerations.

asking: Which of the following does a security group attached to an instance control? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Security groups control the inbound and outbound traffic allowed into and out of instances.

asking: How many security groups can you attach to a single instance in a VPC?

answerOption.description: None, security groups aren’t attached to instances.

rightAnswer.description: An instance must have a security group but can have more than that.

asking: Which of the following can be added to a VPC, in addition to security groups on included instances, to further secure the VPC?

rightAnswer.description: In addition to security groups, NACLs (network access control lists) can be used to further refine inbound and outbound routing into and out of a VPC. Security groups are attached to instances, and NACLs to VPCs, building a complete security picture of your VPC and its instances.

asking: Which of the following statements is true about a custom, user-created NACL?

answerOption.description: A NACL by default allows all traffic out of a VPC.
A NACL by default allows all traffic into a VPC.
A NACL is a virtual firewall for associated subnets.
A NACL functions at the instance level.

rightAnswer.description: NACLs are virtual firewalls, and they operate at the subnet and VPC level rather than at an individual instance level. Also note the words custom, user-created. The default NACL does allow in and out all traffic; created NACLs do not.

asking: What do you use to permit and restrict control of a NACL?

rightAnswer.description: IAM roles and permissions control access to NACLs.

asking: Which of these are true about security groups? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Evaluate all rules before deciding whether to allow traffic
Apply to all instances in the associated subnet

rightAnswer.description: Security groups support only allow rules (A is false). They do evaluate all rules (B is true) and operate at the instance level (C is true). D is false, as security groups aren’t associated with a subnet.

asking: Which of these are true about security groups? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Security groups are stateful and are associated with an instance (or instances), so A and D are true. They are not stateless, and they process all rules rather than processing rules in order.

asking: Which of these are true about NACLs? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: NACLs are stateless; rules must be specified for traffic going both in and out (so A is false, and B is true). They also process rules in order (C is true). They’re associated with subnets, not a particular instance (so D is false).

asking: Which of these are true about NACLs? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Apply to all instances in an associated subnet
Only apply if no security group is present
Evaluate all rules before deciding whether to allow or disallow traffic

rightAnswer.description: NACLs are associated with a subnet (A) and support both allow and deny rules (C). B is false; NACLs and security groups work together. D is false, as rules are processed in order.

asking: In which order are NACLs and security groups evaluated?

answerOption.description: NACLs and security groups are evaluated in parallel.
A NACL is evaluated first, and then the security group.
A security group is evaluated first, and then the NACL.
It depends on the VPC setup.

rightAnswer.description: NACLs are always evaluated first because they exist at the border of a subnet. As security groups are attached to instances, they are not processed until traffic passes through the NACL and into the instance’s subnet.

asking: Which of these statements are true? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: A security group can apply to two instances at the same time.
A NACL applies to all instances within a subnet at the same time.
A security group can apply to only one instance at the same time.
A NACL can apply to only one instance at the same time.

rightAnswer.description: Both security groups and NACLs can—and usually do—apply to multiple instances in a subnet. The NACL applies to all instances within the associate subnet, and a security group can be associated with multiple instances.

asking: With which of the following is a NACL associated?

answerOption.description: A NACL can be associated with all of these.

rightAnswer.description: NACLs are associated with subnets.

asking: Which of the following are true about the default NACL that comes with the default VPC? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: The default NACL allows in and out all traffic, which is somewhat unintuitive. Keep in mind that the default security group disallows inbound traffic, but the default NACL allows that traffic in.

asking: Which of the following are true about a user-created NACL? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Unlike the default NACL that comes with the default VPC, custom NACLs disallow all inbound and outbound traffic by default.

asking: In which order are rules in a NACL evaluated?

answerOption.description: From low to high, using the number on the rule
From high to low, using the number on the rule
From low to high, using the port of the rule
From high to low, using the port of the rule

rightAnswer.description: Each rule in a NACL has a number, and those rules are evaluated using those numbers, moving from low to high.

asking: Which of the following statements is not true? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: A network ACL has separate inbound and outbound rules.
Each subnet in your VPC must be associated with a NACL.
A network ACL can only be associated with a single subnet.

rightAnswer.description: A and C are true. B is false; NACLs are stateless. D is false, because a NACL can be associated with multiple subnets.

asking: With how many subnets can a NACL be associated?

answerOption.description: A NACL is associated with instances, not subnets.
A NACL is associated with VPCs, not subnets.

rightAnswer.description: A NACL is associated with a subnet, not an instance or VPC. It can be associated with a single subnet or multiple subnets.

asking: With how many NACLs can a subnet be associated?

answerOption.description: A subnet is associated with security groups, not NACLs.
A subnet is associated with VPCs, not NACLs.

rightAnswer.description: A subnet is associated with a NACL. However, a subnet can only be associated to a single NACL at a time.

asking: What happens when you associate a NACL with a subnet that already is associated with a different NACL?

answerOption.description: Nothing, both NACLs are associated with the subnet.
You receive an error. You must remove the first NACL to associate the new one.
You receive an error. You must first merge the two NACLs to apply them to a subnet.
The new NACL replaces the previous NACL, and the subnet still only has one NACL association.

rightAnswer.description: A subnet is associated with a NACL but can only be associated to a single NACL at a time.

asking: Which of the following are part of a network ACL rule? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: NACL rules have a rule number, a protocol, a choice of ALLOW or DENY, and a CIDR range and port or port range for inbound and outbound traffic.

asking: Which of the following are part of a network ACL rule? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: NACL rules have a rule number, a protocol, a choice of ALLOW or DENY, and a CIDR range and port or port range for inbound and outbound traffic.

asking: Which of the following inbound rules of a custom NACL would be evaluated first?

rightAnswer.description: Almost none of this detail actually matters. The only key parameter is the rule number. NACLs evaluate lowest-numbered rules first, so Rule #100 would go first, option B.

asking: If all of the following inbound rules existed on a custom NACL, would SSH traffic be allowed?Rule #800 // HTTP // TCP // 80 // 0.0.0.0/0 -> ALLOWRule #100 // HTTPS // TCP // 443 // 0.0.0.0/0 -> ALLOWRule * // All // All // All // 0.0.0.0/0 -> DENYRule #130 // RDP // TCP // 3389 // 192.0.2.0/24 -> ALLOW

answerOption.description: Yes, SSH is included as a default protocol on NACLs.
Yes, SSH is included in the HTTPS protocol.
Only if the SSH access permission in IAM is granted.

rightAnswer.description: SSH is not explicitly mentioned, so it is not allowed on a custom NACL. Every protocol must explicitly be mentioned.

asking: If all of the following inbound rules existed on the default VPC’s default NACL, would SSH traffic be allowed?Rule #800 // HTTP // TCP // 80 // 0.0.0.0/0 -> ALLOWRule #100 // HTTPS // TCP // 443 // 0.0.0.0/0 -> ALLOW

answerOption.description: Yes, the default VPC’s default NACL allows all inbound traffic by default.
Yes, SSH is included in the HTTPS protocol.
Only if the SSH access permission in IAM is granted.

rightAnswer.description: SSH is not explicitly mentioned, but because the question asks about the default NACL on the default VPC, all traffic is allowed in unless explicitly denied.

asking: If all of the following inbound rules existed on a custom NACL, would SSH traffic be allowed?Rule #800 // HTTP // TCP // 80 // 0.0.0.0/0 -> ALLOWRule #100 // HTTPS // TCP // 443 // 0.0.0.0/0 -> ALLOWRule #140 // All // All // All // 0.0.0.0/0 -> DENYRule #120 // SSH // TCP // 22 // 192.0.2.0/24 -> ALLOW

answerOption.description: Yes, but only from the CIDR block 192.0.2.0/24.
Only if the SSH access permission in IAM is granted.

rightAnswer.description: SSH is allowed here, but only from a specific CIDR block.

asking: If all of the following inbound rules existed on a custom NACL, would SSH traffic be allowed?Rule #800 // HTTP // TCP // 80 // 0.0.0.0/0 -> ALLOWRule #100 // HTTPS // TCP // 443 // 0.0.0.0/0 -> ALLOWRule #110 // All // All // All // 0.0.0.0/0 -> DENYRule #120 // SSH // TCP // 22 // 192.0.2.0/24 -> ALLOW

answerOption.description: Yes, but only from the CIDR block 192.0.2.0/24.
Only if the SSH access permission in IAM is granted.

rightAnswer.description: While there is a rule allowing SSH from the CIDR block 192.0.2.0/24, that rule would be evaluated after the lower-numbered rule 110, which disallows any traffic not allowed in from lower-numbered rules (in this case, just rule #100).

asking: Which of the following is the most accurate statement about what the following inbound rule on a NACL will do?Rule #120 // SSH // TCP // 22 // 192.0.2.0/24 -> ALLOW

answerOption.description: Allows inbound SSH traffic to the associated subnets
Allows inbound TCP traffic to the associated subnets
Allows inbound TCP traffic to the associated subnets from the CIDR block 192.0.2.0/24
Allows inbound SSH traffic to the associated subnets from the CIDR block 192.0.2.0/24

rightAnswer.description: Technically, B and C are correct; SSH is a type of TCP traffic. However, that is not the most specific answer, which is what the question asks. A is partially correct but does not call out the CIDR block limitation that D does. Therefore, D is the most accurate answer.

asking: Which of the following is the most accurate statement about what the following inbound rule on a NACL will do?Rule #120 // HTTP // TCP // 80 // 0.0.0.0/0 -> ALLOW

answerOption.description: Allows inbound HTTP traffic to the associated subnets
Allows inbound IPv4 HTTP traffic to the associated subnets as long as it is not pre-vented by lower-numbered rules
Allows inbound IPv4 HTTP traffic to the associated subnets
Allows inbound IPv4 TCP traffic to the associated subnets

rightAnswer.description: The most accurate answer here includes several components: the type of TCP traffic (HTTP), the allowed source CIDR block (the entire Internet), and IPv4. This rule does not explicitly allow IPv6 traffic. Further, this rule is only effective if there are no lower-numbered rules that short-circuit this rule.

asking: What does the CIDR block 0.0.0.0/0 represent?

answerOption.description: The entire Internet, limited to IPv4 addresses
The entire Internet, limited to IPv6 addresses
Inbound traffic from the entire Internet

rightAnswer.description: 0.0.0.0/0 represents IPv4 addresses, and the entire Internet. However, a CIDR block does not represent any type of traffic, inbound or outbound.

asking: What does the CIDR block ::/0 represent?

answerOption.description: The entire Internet, limited to IPv4 addresses
The entire Internet, limited to IPv6 addresses
Inbound traffic from the entire Internet

rightAnswer.description: ::/0 represents IPv6 addresses, and the entire Internet. However, a CIDR block does not represent any type of traffic, inbound or outbound.

asking: Which of the following rules allows IPv6 outbound traffic to flow to the entire Internet through a NAT gateway with the ID nat-123456789?

rightAnswer.description: ::/0 represents IPv6 addresses, so the answer must be either B or D. The route should go from all IPv6 addresses to the ID of the NAT gateway, which is nat-123456789. There is no intermediate -> NAT that should be inserted into the routes.

asking: How many availability zones in a single region does a single VPC span?

answerOption.description: None, VPCs do not span availability zones.

rightAnswer.description: A VPC spans all the availability zones in a region.

asking: Which of these must be specified when creating a new VPC? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: You must always select a region to create a VPC, and you must always provide a CIDR block. VPCs span all the AZs in a region, so that is not required, and security groups are associated at the instance level rather than at the VPC level.

asking: How many subnets can be added to an availability zone within a VPC?

rightAnswer.description: For a single VPC, you can add one or more subnets to each availability zone within that VPC.

asking: To how many availability zones within a region can a single subnet in a VPC be added?

rightAnswer.description: A subnet cannot span availability zones. It can be added to a single AZ.

asking: How many availability zones can a subnet span?

rightAnswer.description: A subnet cannot span availability zones. It can be added to a single AZ and can only exist within that single AZ.

asking: How many IPv6 CIDR blocks can be assigned to a single VPC?

rightAnswer.description: A VPC can have a single primary CIDR block assigned to it for IPv4 addresses and an optional IPv6 CIDR block. While you can add secondary IPv4 CIDR blocks, you cannot add additional CIDR blocks for IPv6 at this time.

asking: How many IPv4 CIDR blocks can be assigned to a single VPC?

rightAnswer.description: A VPC can have a single primary CIDR block assigned to it for IPv4 addresses and an optional IPv6 CIDR block. However, you can add additional secondary CIDR blocks to a VPC (up to four).

asking: You have a VPC in US East 1 with three subnets. One of those subnets’ traffic is routed to an internet gateway. What does this make the subnet?

answerOption.description: The master subnet of that VPC

rightAnswer.description: Any subnet that routes traffic through an internet gateway is a public subnet by definition.

asking: You have a public subnet in a VPC and an EC2 instance serving web traffic within that public subnet. Can that EC2 instance be reached via the Internet?

answerOption.description: Yes, as long as it has a public IPv4 address.
Yes, as long as the VPC is marked as public.

rightAnswer.description: Instances in a public subnet are not automatically reachable. They must have either a public IPv4 or IPv6 address (B) or an elastic IP address.

asking: You have a public subnet within your VPC. Within that subnet are three instances, each running a web-accessible API. Two of the instances are responding to requests from Inter-net clients, but one is not. What could be the problem?

answerOption.description: The VPC needs to be marked as public-facing.
The three instances should be moved into an Auto Scaling group.
There is no internet gateway available for the VPC.
The unavailable instance needs an elastic IP.

rightAnswer.description: A public subnet, as well as existing Internet-accessible instances, indicates a working internet gateway, so C is not correct. A is not an actual AWS option, and B—Auto Scaling—would not address public accessibility. This leaves D, which is correct: Instances in a public subnet that are intended to be Internet accessible need either a public IP address or an elastic IP address assigned to the instance.

asking: Which of the following are allowed when creating a new VPC? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: When creating a VPC, you can specify an option name, a required IPv4 CIDR block, and an optional IPv6 CIDR block.

asking: Which of the following is not a required part of creating a custom VPC? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: When creating a VPC, you can specify an option name, a required IPv4 CIDR block, and an optional IPv6 CIDR block. You cannot assign tags to a VPC at creation time.

asking: Which of the following defines a subnet as a public subnet? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: A security group that allows inbound public traffic
A routing table that routes traffic through the internet gateway

rightAnswer.description: A public subnet is one in which traffic is routed (via a routing table, B) to an internet gateway (D).

asking: Which of the following defines a VPN-only subnet? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: A routing table that routes traffic through the internet gateway
A routing table that routes traffic through the virtual private gateway

rightAnswer.description: A VPN-only subnet routes traffic through a virtual private gateway rather than an internet gateway.

asking: Which of the following are required components in a VPN-only subnet? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: At a minimum, a VPC-only subnet must have a routing table routing traffic and a virtual private gateway to which traffic is routed. Neither elastic IP addresses nor internet gateways are required.

asking: By default, how many VPCs can you create per region?

rightAnswer.description: You can only create 5 VPCs per region by default. Creating more requires a request to AWS.

asking: By default, how many subnets can you create per VPC?

rightAnswer.description: This is a high number, but accurate: You can create 200 subnets per VPC.

asking: By default, how many IPv4 CIDR blocks can you create per VPC?

rightAnswer.description: This is a very hard question, but it can come up, albeit rarely. This limit is your primary CIDR block and then, in addition, 4 secondary CIDR blocks.

asking: By default, how many elastic IPs can you create per region?

rightAnswer.description: You’re allowed 5 elastic IP addresses per region, unless you have the default limits raised by AWS.

asking: Which of the following is not true? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: A subnet can have the same CIDR block as the VPC within which it exists.
A subnet can have a larger CIDR block than the VPC within which it exists.
A subnet can have a smaller CIDR block than the VPC within which it exists.
A subnet does not have to have a CIDR block specified.

rightAnswer.description: Subnets must have CIDR blocks (so D is false), and the block must be the same as or smaller than the CIDR block for the VPC within which it exists, so while A and C are true, B is false.

asking: A VPC peering connection connects a VPC to which of the following?

answerOption.description: A specific instance within another VPC

rightAnswer.description: A VPC peering connection connects one VPC to another VPC via networking and routing.

asking: An Amazon VPC VPN connection links your on-site network to which of the following?

rightAnswer.description: A VPC VPN connection links your on-site network to a VPC within the AWS cloud.

asking: Which of the following are required for a VPC VPN connection? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: A VPC VPN connection requires a customer gateway, a VPN connection, and a virtual private gateway.

asking: Which of the following would you use to secure a VPC and its instances? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Customer gateways (A) and virtual private gateways (C) are used in VPN connections. For security, a NACL (B) is used at the subnet level, and a security group (D) can be used at the instance level.

asking: You want to ensure that no incoming traffic reaches any instances in your VPC. Which of the following is your best option to prevent this type of traffic?

rightAnswer.description: A NACL is best for dealing with all traffic at a subnet or VPC level, as it is associated at the subnet level.

asking: You want to ensure that no incoming traffic reaches just the database instances in a par-ticular subnet within your VPC. Which of the following is your best option to prevent this type of traffic?

rightAnswer.description: Anytime you are protecting or limiting traffic to or from specific instances, a security group is your best choice. Security groups are associated with specific instances, so they can effectively limit traffic to some instances while allowing other instances—using different security groups—to still be accessible.

asking: You have a subnet with five instances within it. Two are serving public APIs and three are providing backend compute power through database instances. What is the best way to secure these instances? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Apply NACLs at the subnet level.
Attach a single security group to all the instances.
Move the two backend database instances into a different subnet.
Attach an internet gateway to the VPC.

rightAnswer.description: This takes a little careful reading. First, it is not considered a good practice to mix private and public instances within a subnet—although this is not a hard-and-fast rule. So C, moving the private database instances into a different subnet, is at least worth considering. D is not helpful in this case. If you have two subnets, one private and one public, then A is a good idea: NACLs can protect one subnet and keep another public. Finally, B is not valid, because of the word single. You cannot have a single security group that allows traffic to one instance but not to another. This leaves A and C as the best combined solution.

asking: Security groups operate most like which of the following?

rightAnswer.description: A security group denies all traffic unless explicitly allowed. This means it functions as a whitelist: Only specific rules allow in traffic, and all other traffic is denied.

asking: If you have a NACL and a security group, at what two levels is security functioning? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: A security group operates at the instance level, and a NACL operates at the subnet level.

asking: What type of filtering does a security group perform?

rightAnswer.description: A security group performs stateful filtering, meaning that traffic allowed in is automatically allowed back out, without the need for an explicit outbound rule.

asking: What type of filtering does a network ACL perform?

rightAnswer.description: Network ACLs are stateless. Inbound traffic is not automatically allowed back out; an explicit rule must be present for traffic to move from within a subnet back out of that subnet.

asking: With which of the following can you create a VPC peering connection?

answerOption.description: A VPC in the same AWS account and same region
A VPC in another AWS account
A VPC in the same AWS account but in another region

rightAnswer.description: VPC peering allows a VPC to connect with any other VPC: in the same region, in a different region, or in a different account altogether.

asking: With which of the following can you not create a VPC peering connection? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: A VPC in another AWS account
An instance in the same region
A VPC in the same region

rightAnswer.description: VPC peering allows a VPC to connect with any other VPC, so the options that don’t involve VPCs are incorrect: B and D.

asking: You have an instance within a custom VPC, and that instance needs to communicate with an API published by an instance in another VPC. How can you make this possible? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Enable cross-VPC communication via the AWS console.
Configure routing from the source instance to the API-serving instance.
Add a security group to the source instance.
Add an internet gateway or virtual private gateway to the source VPC.

rightAnswer.description: As long as there is a gateway (internet or virtual private) on the source VPC, and routing through that gateway, an instance in a VPC can communicate with other instances. So in this case, you’d want B and D. There is no “cross-VPC communication” option, and security groups won’t actually help this scenario.

asking: Which of the following could be used to allow instances within one VPC to communicate with instances in another region? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: This is a little difficult, but it comes down to accessibility: How can the target instance be reached? Of the answers available, a public IP would make the target available, as would a VPN connection.

asking: Which region does not currently support VPCs?

answerOption.description: VPC is supported in all AWS regions.

rightAnswer.description: VPCs are fundamental to AWS networking and are available in all AWS regions.

asking: How many availability zones can a VPC span?

answerOption.description: None, VPCs don’t exist within availability zones.
All the availability zones within a region

rightAnswer.description: A VPC automatically spans all the availability zones within the region in which it exists.

asking: When you launch an instance within a VPC, in which availability zone is it launched?

answerOption.description: You must specify an availability zone.
The first availability zone without an instance
The availability zone with the least resources utilized

rightAnswer.description: When you launch an instance, you must specify an availability zone. This could be as simple as accepting the AWS default, but it is your choice.

asking: You are the architect at a company that requires all data at rest to be encrypted. You dis-cover several EBS-backed EC2 instances that will be commissioned in the next week. How can you ensure that data on these volumes will be encrypted?

answerOption.description: Use OS-level tools on the instance to encrypt the volumes.
Specify via the AWS console that the volumes should be encrypted when they are  created.
You cannot enable encryption on a specific EBS volume.
Start the instances with the volumes and then encrypt them via the AWS console.

rightAnswer.description: EBS volumes can be encrypted, but it must be done at launch time (B).

asking: Which of the following is required to use a VPC endpoint?

answerOption.description: A VPC endpoint does not require any of these.

rightAnswer.description: A VPC endpoint is a connection to an AWS service and explicitly does not use internet gateways, VPN connections, or NAT devices.

asking: Which of the following is not true about a VPC endpoint?

answerOption.description: A VPC endpoint can attach to an S3 bucket.
A VPC endpoint is a hardware device.
A VPC endpoint does not require an internet gateway.
Traffic to a VPC endpoint does not travel over the Internet.

rightAnswer.description: A VPC endpoint is a virtual device, not a physical one.

asking: To which of the following can a VPC endpoint not attach?

rightAnswer.description: A VPC endpoint is for attaching to AWS services and explicitly does not require an internet gateway (C).

asking: Which of the following might you need to create for using a VPC endpoint attached to S3?

rightAnswer.description: By default, IAM users don’t have permissions to work with endpoints. You may need to create an IAM role. You would not need a NAT device (A or B) or a security group (D) to use a VPC endpoint.

asking: Is it possible to SSH into a subnet with no public instances?

answerOption.description: Yes, as long as you have a bastion host and correct routing.
Yes, as long as you have an AWS Direct Connect.

rightAnswer.description: A private subnet is not accessible without a bastion host or other connection and routing from the public Internet to an accessible host and finally into private instances.

asking: Where should a bastion host be located?

answerOption.description: In a VPC with a virtual private gateway

rightAnswer.description: Bastion hosts should be in a public subnet so that they can be accessed via the public Internet. They can then route traffic into a private subnet.

asking: What is another name for a bastion host?

rightAnswer.description: Bastion hosts are also sometimes called jump servers, because they allow a connection to “jump” to the bastion and then into a private subnet.

asking: To which of the following might a bastion host be used to connect?

answerOption.description: A public instance in a public subnet
A public instance in a private subnet
A private instance in a public subnet
A private instance in a private subnet

rightAnswer.description: Bastion hosts are intended to provide access to private instances in private subnets; in other words, instances inaccessible via the public Internet in any other way.

asking: Which of these would you use to secure a bastion host?

rightAnswer.description: Bastion hosts are publicly accessible and have access to your private hosts. Therefore, they must be the most secure hosts on your network. Use a network ACL for the subnet in which it resides, a security group for the instance, and OS hardening to reduce access within the instance itself.

asking: For a bastion host intended to provide shell access to your private instances, what proto-cols should you allow via a security group?

rightAnswer.description: Shell access only requires SSH, and you should therefore only allow that protocol. Always allow only what is absolutely required for bastion hosts.

asking: Which of the following statements about internet gateways is false?

rightAnswer.description: Internet gateways scale horizontally, not vertically. They are also redundant and highly available automatically.

asking: To which of the following does an internet gateway attach?

rightAnswer.description: Internet gateways attach to VPCs and serve multiple subnets (if needed).

asking: Which of the following destination routes would be used for routing IPv4 traffic to an internet gateway?

rightAnswer.description: The route 0.0.0.0/0 catches all IPv4 traffic intended for the public Internet. ::/0 is for IPv6, 0.0.0.0/24 limits traffic to a certain CIDR block, and D is an internal IP address.

asking: Which of the following destination routes would be used for routing IPv6 traffic to an internet gateway?

rightAnswer.description: The route ::/0 catches all IPv6 traffic intended for the public Internet. 0.0.0.0/0 is for IPv6, 0.0.0.0/24 limits traffic to a certain CIDR block, and D is an internal IP address.

asking: Which of the following is not necessary for an instance to have IPv6 communication over the Internet?

answerOption.description: A VPC with an associated IPv6 CIDR block
A public IPv6 assigned to the instance
A subnet with an associated IPv6 CIDR block
A virtual private gateway with IPv6 enabled

rightAnswer.description: An instance must have IPv6 communication from itself (with a public IP address) through a subnet with IPv6 addresses, in a VPC with IPv6 addresses, to reach the Internet via IPv6. A virtual private gateway is not connected with any of these.

asking: Which of the following are possible options for assigning to an instance that needs public access? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: For an instance to reach and be reached to and from the public Internet, the instance must have either a public IP address or an elastic IP address associated with it. IAM roles do not provide public access, and NACLs are attached to subnets, not instances.

asking: Which of the following will have internet gateways available? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: A public subnet, by definition, is a subnet with an internet gateway attached. And the default VPC has an internet gateway automatically attached.

asking: What does ALB stand for?

rightAnswer.description: ALB stands for application load balancer.

asking: At what OSI layer does an application load balancer operate?

rightAnswer.description: Application load balancers operate at the Application layer, which is layer 7 of the OSI model. ELBs (classic load balancers) operate at the Transport layer, layer 4, as well as layer 7, and network load balancers operate at layer 4 as well.

asking: At what OSI layer does a network load balancer operate?

rightAnswer.description: Application load balancers operate at the Application layer, which is layer 7 of the OSI model. ELBs (classic load balancers) operate at the Transport layer, layer 4, as well as layer 7, and network load balancers operate at layer 4 as well.

asking: At what OSI layer does a classic load balancer operate?

rightAnswer.description: Application load balancers operate at the Application layer, which is layer 7 of the OSI model. ELBs (classic load balancers) operate at the Transport layer, layer 4, as well as layer 7, and network load balancers operate at Level 4 as well.

asking: Which type of load balancer operates at the Transport layer?

answerOption.description: Both classic and network load balancers

rightAnswer.description: Both network and classic load balancers operate at the Transport layer. Classic load balancers also operate at layer 7, the Application layer. Application load balancers operate at the Application layer, which is layer 7 of the OSI model.

asking: Which type of load balancer operates at the Application layer?

answerOption.description: Both classic and application load balancers

rightAnswer.description: Both classic and application load balancers operate at the Application layer. Classic load balancers also operate at layer 4, the Transport layer. Network load balancers operate at the Transport layer, which is layer 4 of the OSI model.

asking: What type of subnets are the default subnets in the default VPC?

rightAnswer.description: By default, subnets in the default VPC are public. The default VPC has an internet gateway attached and the default subnets are public as a result.

asking: What type of subnets are the default subnets in a custom VPC?

rightAnswer.description: By default, subnets in custom VPCs are private. Other than the default VPC, custom VPCs don’t have internet gateways attached by default, and created subnets don’t have public access.

asking: Which of the following is not automatically created for an instance launched into a non-default subnet?

answerOption.description: A route to other instances in the subnet

rightAnswer.description: Instances launched into non-default subnets have a private IPv4 address, but not a public one, so C is correct. All instances have a security group created or associated, and instances can always talk to other instances in the subnet by default.

asking: Which of the following would be needed to allow an instance launched into a non-default subnet Internet access? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Instances launched into non-default subnets have a private IPv4 address, but not a public one, so they need an elastic IP address, as answer C indicates. (A public IP address would work as well.) You’d also need an internet gateway for the instance (D).

asking: Which of the following would you need to add or create to allow an instance launched into a default subnet in the default VPC Internet access?

rightAnswer.description: Instances launched into default subnets in the default VPC can automatically reach out to the public Internet, as that VPC has an internet gateway and instances get a public IPv4 address.

asking: Which of the following would you use to allow outbound Internet traffic while preventing unsolicited inbound connections?

rightAnswer.description: A NAT device—network address translation—provides routing for instances to an internet gateway but can prevent undesired inbound traffic.

asking: What does a NAT device allow?

answerOption.description: Incoming traffic from the Internet to reach private instances
Incoming traffic from other VPCs to reach private instances
Outgoing traffic to other VPCs from private instances
Outgoing traffic to the Internet from private instances

rightAnswer.description: A NAT device provides access to the Internet from private instances—they allow outgoing traffic rather than incoming traffic.

asking: Which of the following are NAT devices offered by AWS? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: AWS offers two NAT devices: a NAT instance and a NAT gateway.

asking: Which of the following requires selecting an AMI? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Instances always require an AMI. In this question, the two instances are EC2 instances (A) and NAT instances (D).

asking: For which of the following do you not need to worry about operating system updates?

rightAnswer.description: A NAT gateway is an entirely managed device from AWS. All the other options require maintenance by the user of OS-level patches and updates.

asking: Which of the following does not automatically scale to meet demand?

rightAnswer.description: A NAT instance does not provide automatic scaling, whereas DynamoDB and NAT gateways are managed services and do. There is really no such thing as “scaling” of an SNS topic, although SNS as a service does do some scaling in the background to ensure that demand is met.

asking: Which of the following, without proper security, could be most dangerous to your private instances?

rightAnswer.description: Of these options, only bastion hosts and NAT instances are unmanaged services, making them the only two possible answers. A bastion host typically has SSH routing and permissions to private instances, making it the most important to properly secure. While a NAT instance is usually available to private instances, traffic flows out from the NAT instance and not into the private instances.

asking: Which of the following could be used as a bastion host?

rightAnswer.description: A NAT instance is a candidate for a bastion server. The other options are all managed services.

asking: You are building out a site-to-site VPN connection from an on-site network to a private subnet within a custom VPC. Which of the following might you need for this connection to function properly? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: A site-to-site VPN connection requires a virtual private gateway on the VPC side (C) and a customer gateway on the on-site side (D).

asking: You are building out a site-to-site VPN connection from an on-site network to a custom VPC. Which of the following might you need for this connection to function properly? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: A site-to-site connection is going to require a private subnet on the AWS side (C), with private instances within it. Further, you’ll need a NAT instance (A) or similar device to route traffic and receive traffic as a static IP holder.

asking: With which of the following is an egress-only internet gateway most closely associated?

rightAnswer.description: An egress-only gateway is for use with IPv6 traffic only.

asking: You are responsible for securing an EC2 instance with an IPv6 address that resides in a public subnet. You want to allow traffic from the instance to the Internet but restrict access to the instance. Which of the following would you suggest?

rightAnswer.description: An egress-only gateway is for use with IPv6 traffic and only allows outbound traffic. A VPC endpoint connects to managed AWS services, and an internet gateway (that isn’t egress only) allows both inbound and outbound traffic. A NAT gateway is for allowing outbound traffic from a private subnet rather than a public subnet.

asking: You have just created a NAT instance and want to launch the instance into a subnet. Which of these need to be true of the subnet into which you want to deploy? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: The subnet has routing into the private subnets in your VPC.
The subnet has routing to the public subnets in your VPC.

rightAnswer.description: A NAT instance must be in a public subnet so that it is accessible from the Internet. It also must have access to private instances in private subnets in your VPC.

asking: Which of the following are true about an egress-only internet gateway? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Egress-only internet gateways are stateful and support IPv6 traffic. This is a matter of memorization, although you can somewhat reason that the gateway—absent a NACL—allows responses to come back to instances that use it to communicate with the public Internet.

asking: Which of these would be used as the destination address in a routing table for a VPC that uses an egress-only internet gateway?

rightAnswer.description: The most important thing here is to remember that egress-only internet gateways only work with IPv6 addresses. This eliminates A and B. Then, only C addresses the entire public Internet in an IPv6 format.

asking: Which of the following are true about IPv6 addresses? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: They are in the format x.y.z.w.

rightAnswer.description: IPv6 addresses are public by default (D) because they are globally unique. There is no need to have private IPv6 addresses because the range is so large.

asking: What is an elastic network interface? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: A hardware network interface on an EC2 instance
An interface that can have one or more IPv6 addresses
An interface that does not have a MAC address

rightAnswer.description: An elastic network interface is virtual and can have multiple IPv4 and IPv6 addresses as well as security groups, a MAC address, and a source/destination check flag.

asking: Which of the following is not part of an elastic network interface?

rightAnswer.description: An elastic network interface is virtual and can have multiple IPv4 and IPv6 addresses as well as security groups, a MAC address, and a source/destination check flag. NACLs apply to subnets, though, not network interfaces on instances.

asking: How many network interfaces can a single instance have?

answerOption.description: At least two, up to five

rightAnswer.description: An instance has a primary network interface in all cases but can have additional network interfaces attached, so the answer is C, one or more.

asking: If an elastic network interface is moved from one instance to another, what happens to network traffic directed at the interface?

answerOption.description: It is redirected to the elastic network interface that has moved to the new instance.
It is redirected to the primary network interface on the original instance.
It is redirected to the primary network interface on the new instance.
It is lost and must be re-sent to the elastic network interface on the new instance.

rightAnswer.description: Traffic follows the network interface rather than sticking to any particular instance. So in this case, traffic is redirected to the new instance but stays targeted at the elastic network interface (A).

asking: To how many instances can an elastic network interface be attached?

answerOption.description: One at a time, but it can be moved from one instance to another.

rightAnswer.description: An elastic network interface can only be attached to a single instance at one time but can be moved from one instance to another.

asking: Which of these is not a reason to attach multiple network interfaces to an instance?

answerOption.description: You are creating a management network.
You are attempting to increase network throughput to the instance.
You need a high-availability solution and have a low budget.
